text.headline: Go Olympic time-traveling with LA Metro
text.text: Between Aug. 5 and 19 you can catch some of USA's Olympic Gold medalists of old and different Metro stops throughout the city. They will all be at their relative stops from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. donning Team USA attire with gold medals on display and ready to take selfies with you. Here's who you can find and where you can find them.

text.headline: Aug. 5: Paul Gonzales
text.text: Meet 1984 boxing light flyweight champion, Paul Gonzales, who brought home gold during the L.A. Games. He'll be at the El Monte Bus Station, 3501 Santa Anita Ave, on from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. Aug. 5.

text.headline: Aug. 8: Shirley Babashoff
text.text: Drop by Union Station between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Aug. 8 to meet three-time gold medal-winning swimmer Shirley Babashoff. She competed in the 1976 Montreal Games and the 1972 Munich Games.

text.headline: Aug. 9: John Naber
text.text: Aug. 9 is the first of two opportunities to meet Olympic swimmer John Naber. He has four gold medals from the 1976 Montreal Games — each won in a world record time. Drop by the Sierra Madre Villa Station of the Metro Gold Line from 4:30 to 6 p.m. to meet him.

text.headline: Aug. 10: John Naber
text.text: If you can't make it to see Olympic swimmer John Naber on Aug. 9, catch him Aug. 10 from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. at the Culver City Station of the Metro Expo Line.

text.headline: Aug. 11:  Julianne McNamara
text.text: Meet Julianne McNamara, who scored a perfect 10.0 in the 1984 L.A. Games uneven parallel bars competition. You can find her and her gold medal at the from 4:30 to 6 p.m. on Aug. 11 at the North Hollywood Station of the Metro Red Line

text.headline: Aug. 12: Brenda Villa
text.text: Meet Brenda Villa, gold medal-winning water polo player from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. Aug. 12 at the Atlantic Station of the Metro Gold Line. She competed in the 2012 London Games.

text.headline: Aug. 15: Rafer Johnson
text.text: The "World's Greatest Athlete" Rafer Johnson brought home the gold medal for decathlon at the 1960 Olympic Games in Rome, where he was also the U.S. Flag Bearer. You can meet him from 4:30 to 6 p.m. Aug. 15 at the Chatsworth Station of the Metro Orange Line.

text.headline: Aug. 16: Valerie Brisco
text.text: Valerie Brisco has three gold medals from the 1984 L.A. Games for running in the 200 meters, 400 meters and 4x400 meters relay. You can meet her between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Aug. 16 at the 7th Street/Metro Center.

text.headline: Aug. 17: Lisa Fernandez
text.text: You can celebrate the announcement of softball's return for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo while taking selfies with three-time gold medal winner Lisa Fernandez. She pitched for Team USA in the 1996, 2000 and 2004 Olympics. Meet her between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Aug. 17 at Downtown Long Beach Station of the Metro Blue Line.

text.headline: Aug. 18: Bryan Clay
text.text: Another Olympic decathlon winning "World's Greatest Athlete" is Bryan Clay. He won the gold for decathlon at the 2008 Beijing Games. Meet him between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Aug. 18 at the APU/Citrus College Station of the Metro Gold Line.

text.headline: Aug. 19: Mark Spitz
text.text: Meet nine-time Olympic gold medal swimmer Mark Spitz between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Aug. 19 at Downtown Santa Monica Station of the Metro Expo Line. He competed in the 1968 Mexico City Games and the 1972 Munich Games, where he won seven gold medals in world record times.
